intro: Solenopsis laurentia subsp. laurentia, commonly known as the Laurentian antplant, is a species of flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and its ability to produce a variety of small, showy flowers. The plant has specialized structures called "pseudobulbs" that store water and nutrients, aiding in its survival in arid environments. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is often found in sandy or rocky soils. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for study in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
